request.description:
Gets the number of unique users subscribed to a set of metrics specified in a comma separated list of metric LUIDs. For metrics with group followers, the count will be the union of all the members of the subscribed groups plus all the individual followers. Users are counted only once per metric. > **Version:** Available in API 3.21 (Tableau Cloud December 2023) and later. Not available for Tableau Server. *[Versioning Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm)* > **Permissions:** Any user that has **read** or **connect** permission to the data source used in the definition can create subscriptions. *[Permissions Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_permissions.htm)* > **License:** No additional license required. > **Access Scope:** tableau:metric_subscriptions:read

item.description:
With Tableau Pulse, Tableau Cloud users can follow metrics and use guided exploration to understand more about their data. In addition to viewing metrics from the Tableau Pulse home page, users can receive digests via Slack or email that include insights into important changes in their data so users can stay up to date. ### Tableau Pulse Overview - A **metric definition** specifies the metadata for all related metrics created using the definition. This includes the data source, measure, time dimension, and which data source dimensions can be filtered by users or programmatically to create related metrics. - Example: A metric definition might specify that the data source is the Superstore sales database, and that the measure to focus on is the aggregation "sum of sales". It could define the filterable dimensions as region and product line, that the time dimension for analysis is order date, and that the favorable direction is for the metric to increase.

- A **metric** is the interactive object that users follow and receive updates on. It specifies the values to give the filterable dimensions of the metric's definition and the measurement time period of the metric. - Example: A user or REST request could filter the metric, and its automatically generated insights, based on the West region and product line sold. The insight provided might call out that discounted sales have risen sharply in a region between last quarter and the current one.

- A user who follows (has a **subscription** to) a metric can receive digests via email or Slack. Digests can also be viewed in the Metrics home page in the Tableau UI.

- A digest provides summary visualizations and text describing the top **insight**s for a metric. It also displays links to further metric details and to suggested follow up questions based on the metric's data and insights.

- An **insight** is a data-driven observation about a metric.Tableau automatically generates and ranks insights by usefulness. - An **insight bundle** is a collection of insights for a metric That can be configured to include various elements. For more information and to learn about the UI features related to these methods, see [Create Pulse Metrics](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/pulse_create_metrics.htm). ### Configuring Pulse insights for a metric You can use Pulse REST API methods to generate an insight bundle for a metric. An insight bundle request specifies the metric being analyzed, the output format (text or HTML), time frame, and additional filters for the insights in the bundle. In the request, you configure the type of insight **bundle** that should be provided for a metric. Types include: - `basic` - Contains the current number, percentage, or currency value aggregated for the metric. - `springboard` - Contains period-over-period change, time series, and the top-ranked insight that exceed a "usefulness" score. - `detail` - Contains all ranked insights and follow up suggestions for a metric. > **Process suggestion:** Bundles are rich and complex objects that can be challenging to build manually. One approach to efficiently create the JSON for a bundle is to use the Tableau user interface to create the form of metric definition and metrics you want to produce programmatically. Then you can navigate to a metric and use your browsers' inspector to view and copy the JSON response for the insight bundle. You can use the JSON directly or as a template in your code. ### Insight types Depending on the type of insight bundle you request and the shape of your data source, some or all of the following types of insights will be returned. | Value | Name | Description | | ----------------- | ----------------- |----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | popc | Period over Period Change | Shows how a metric has changed between two periods. Highlights the change between a metric value for a recent time range compared to an equivalent time range in a prior period or the past. | | riskmo | Risky Monopoly | Shows when a small number of dimension members make up a majority (50% or more) of the contribution to a metric. Shows dimensions with a concentration of very high values.

A risky monopoly is a situation when a small number of dimension members make up a majority (50% or more) of the contribution to a metric. | | top-contributors | Top Contributors | Shows the highest values in a dimension for a metric within a given time range.

A top contributor is a dimension member that ranks in the top N in contribution to the scoped metric’s value, aggregated on a specified time range. | | top-contributors | Bottom Contributors | Shows the lowest values in a dimension for a metric within a given time range. A bottom contributor is a dimension member that ranks in the bottom N in contribution to the scoped metric’s value, aggregated on a specified time range. | | top-drivers | Top Drivers | Shows values for dimension members that changed the most in the same direction as the observed change in the metric. Shows the values for a metric that increased the most across a specified time offset.

A top driver is a dimension member that ranks in the top N in driving a change in a metric value between two separate but equivalent time ranges.

Top drivers are analyzed using metric values from two separate but equivalent time ranges (such as Sales for day of October 2 versus Sales for day of October 3) to look for changes to the contributions in the same direction of the change made by dimension members. | | top-detractors | Top Detractors | Shows values for dimension members that changed the most in the opposite direction to the observed change in the metric. Shows values for a metric that are most opposed to top drivers decreased the most across a specified time offset.

A top detractor is a dimension member that ranks in the bottom N in driving a change in a metric value between two separate but equivalent time ranges. This insight's values oppose the observed change the most.

Top detractors are analyzed using metric values from two separate but equivalent time ranges (such as Sales for day of October 2 versus Sales for day of October 3) to look for changes to the contributions in the same direction of the change made by dimension members. | | unusualchange | Unusually High/Low Metric value | Shows unexpected changes in a metric value.

Shows when the value of a metric for a given time range is higher or lower than the expected range based on historic observations of the metric.

This insight highlights when the value of a metric for a given time range is higher or lower than the expected range based on historic observations of the metric. | | newtrend | New Trend Detected | Shows new trends that vary significantly from the current trend. This insight communicates the rate of change, direction, and fluctuations for the metric value. | ### What do Pulse REST API methods enable? > Metric definitions >
    >
  • Create, update, and delete metric definitions
    • >
  • Get a list of metric definitions for a site
    • >
  • Get a list of metrics for a metric definition
    • >
  • Get a specified batch of metric definitions
    • >
> Metrics >
    >
  • Get the details of a metric
    • >
  • Get a metric if it exists or create it if it doesn't
    • >
  • Create, update, and delete a metric
    • >
  • Get a specified batch of metrics
    • >
> Metric Insights >
    >
  • Generate a basic insight bundle for a metric
    • >
  • Generate a springboard insight bundle for a metric
    • >
  • Generate a detail insight bundle for a metric
    • >
> Metric Subscriptions >
    >
  • Get the details of a subscription to a metric
    • >
  • Get a list of subscriptions to a metric for a user
    • >
  • Create or delete a subscription to a metric
    • >
  • Update the followers of a metric
    • >
  • Get a specified batch of subscriptions to a metric
    • >
  • Create subscriptions for a batch of users or groups to a metric
    • >
  • Get a count of followers for a specified batch of subscriptions to a metric
    • >

# Tableau REST API Collection The Tableau REST API enables you to perform many Tableau actions from scripts and programs. You can use this collection to make requests to your Tableau site and see the response, without creating an app to do it. ### Get Started To get started, see [How to Use the Collection](https://github.com/tableau/tableau-postman/blob/main/README.md#how-to-use-the-collection). ### Contribute This collection is open source and we welcome your contributions by [creating a Postman pull request for a fork](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collaborating-in-postman/using-version-control/version-control-overview/). See [Contributing](https://github.com/tableau/tableau-postman/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more info. ### Issues You can find and create issues with the collection in [tableau-postman GitHub repo issues](https://github.com/tableau/tableau-postman/issues). ### Learn more For REST API method details and behaviors, see the [Tableau REST API Reference](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api.htm). To get familiar with the REST API try the [Get Started Tutorial](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_get_started_tutorial_intro.htm).

item.name: Tableau Metadata API (GraphQL)
Authentication - (See Tableau REST API methods)
item.description: To use the Tableau Metadata API, you should use the authentication methods from the Tableau REST API folder.

The Tableau Metadata API discovers and indexes all of the content on your Tableau Cloud site or Tableau Server, including workbooks, data sources, flows, and metrics. Indexing is used to gather information about Tableau content, or metadata, about the schema and lineage of the content. Then from the metadata, Metadata API identifies all of the databases, files, and tables used by the content on your Tableau Cloud site or Tableau Server.

## Use Cases

Query for databases, data sources, and views. See which workbooks depend on a column or fields in a table. Evaluate the downstream impact of migrating a database and then identify content owners that might be impacted by the change.

## Benefits

- Discover data and metadata used across your organization.
- Track lineage to get a complete view of your data.
    

## Authentication

For authentication, see Tableau REST API > Authenticate.

For more information see: [https://www.tableau.com/developer/tools/metadata-api](https://www.tableau.com/developer/tools/metadata-api)

item.name: VizQL Data Service

request.description:
## Description

Requests metadata for a specific data source. The metadata provides information about the data fields, such as field names, data types, and more. The fields returned from this request can be passed to the request body of Query Datasource to return data from the datasource.

See [Get Data Source Information](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/vizql-data-service/en-us/docs/vds_get_data_source_info.html)

## Description

Requests the data model for a given datasource. Returns a lit of logical table names and ids in the data model, as well as a list of relationships between the logical tables.

See [Get Data Source Information](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/vizql-data-service/en-us/docs/vds_get_data_source_info.html)

## Description

Queries a specific data source for the specified fields and returns the resulting data.

See [Create a Query](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/vizql-data-service/en-us/docs/vds_create_queries.html)

## Examples

You'll note the examples for this request are all example queries for the sample Superstore Datasource. To query a different data source, replace the fields in these examples with fields from the intended datasource.

item.description:
# VizQL Data Service Collection

The VizQL Data Service provides a programmatic way for you to access data from your published data sources. Use this collection to retrieve data and field metadata from a specific data source.

See full documentation here: [VizQL Data Service](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/vizql-data-service/en-us/index.html)

### Get started

To get started, see [How to Use the Collection](https://github.com/tableau/tableau-postman/blob/main/README.md#how-to-use-the-collection).

## Authentication

For authentication, see **Tableau REST API** > **Authenticate**.

## Find your data source LUID

After signing in using the Tableau REST API, you'll need to populate the `datasource-id` field in your Tableau REST API environment variables to query a specific data source.

## Query data source examples from the Superstore data source

All of the example queries under Query Data Source use fields from the Superstore data source to illustrate our request body syntax. To run these examples, make sure your `datasource-id` environment variable points to the Superstore data source.

To automatically set your `datasource-id` environment variable to the Superstore data source, go to the **Sample Workflows** > **VizQL Data Service Queries** > **Query Data Sources** and send the GET request. This has a post request script that searches for a data source on your site called SuperstoreDatasource and, if found, sets the `datasource-id` to point there.

item.description:
In this workflow, we:

1\. Authenticate with JWT to sign in.

2\. Execute an authenticated GET request (e.g., Query Group).

3\. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token.

4\. Attempt the same GET request, which fails due to the invalidated token.

> Note: While this workflow uses JWT via Connected Apps for authentication, alternative authentication mechanisms are also available
This folder is a collection of workflows that relates to Authentication.

item.description:
Prerequisites

- This workflow requires an existing workbook named "Superstore". A "Superstore" workbook is available on newly deployed Tableau instances such as the free Tableau Cloud Developer Sandbox that [can be requested through Tableau.com](https://www.tableau.com/developer/get-site).
    

In this workflow, we:

1. Authenticate with Admin PAT to sign in
2. Search for the Workbook **"Superstore"**, and store the `workbook-id` and `workbook-name` variables
    
3. Get information about workbook **"Superstore"**, and find no tags
4. Add the tag **"NewTag"** to the workbook **"Superstore"**
5. Get information about workbook **"Superstore"** and find the newly created tag **"NewTag"**
6. Delete tag **"NewTag"**
7. Get information about workbook **"Superstore"**, and find no tags which is expected since we deleted **"NewTag"**
8. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token
    

> Note: This workflow uses Admin PAT authentication since JWT is not yet supported for the `Add Tags to a Workbook` method (as of API version 3.22)

query.description: (Optional) An expression that lets you specify a subset of workbooks to return. You can filter on predefined fields such as name, tags, and createdAt. You can include multiple filter expressions. For more information, see Filtering and Sorting.

(Optional) An expression that lets you specify the order in which workbook information is returned. If you do not specify a sort expression, the sort order of the information that's returned is undefined. For more information, see Filtering and Sorting.

You can qualify the return values based upon predefined keywords such as _all_ or _default_, and you can specify individual fields for the workbooks or other supported resources. You can include multiple field expressions in a request. For more information, see Using Fields in the REST API.

(Optional) The extract-value is a Boolean value (False or True). When the workbook specified for download has an extract, if you add the parameter ?includeExtract=False, the extract is not included when you download the workbook. You can use this option to improve performance if you are downloading workbooks or data sources that have large extracts.

formdata.value:
<tsRequest>
	<workbook name="Postman Workflow Published Workbook" showTabs="true" >
		<project id="{{project-id}}"/>
	</workbook>
</tsRequest>

query.description: (Optional) true to overwrite a workbook that has the same name, or false to fail if the specified workbook already exists. The default is false. If overwrite-flag is set to true but the workbook doesn't already exist, the operation succeeds.

(Optional, boolean) If true, then the Tableau server will not check if a non-published connection of a workbook is reachable. Publishing will succeed but unchecked connection issues may result in a non-functioning workbook. If you encounter this issue, follow Keep Data Fresh guidelines(Link opens in a new window). Default value is false.

twb or twbx to indicate whether you have uploaded a workbook file (twb) or a packaged workbook file (twbx). This value is required if you are calling Publish Workbook in order to commit a file that was previously uploaded using Append to File Upload. The value is not used if you upload a file in the body of the request.

If you are calling this method to commit a file that was uploaded in parts, this value contains the upload session ID that was generated by a call to Initiate File Upload. If this value is not included, the server assumes that the body of the request contains the file to be published.

(Optional, boolean) If false, the workbook publishing process runs as a synchronous process. If a workbook is very large, the process might time out before it finishes. If you set this value to true, the process runs asynchronously, and a job will start to perform the publishing process and return the job ID. You can check the status of the import job by calling Query Job. Default value is false.

item.description: ## ⚠️ Manual Flow ⚠️ Due to a Postman [incompatibility](https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/issues/11471) (as of 05/11/24), this workflow can't use the Postman "Run" feature but requires to manually trigger the API calls by: - Selecting the method in the left folder panel - Clicking the **Send** button in the top right corner - Repeat the above for the next method ## Prerequisites - This workflow requires an existing workbook named **"Superstore"** ideally located in a project named **"Sample"**. A **"Superstore"** workbook is available on newly deployed Tableau instances such as the free Tableau Cloud Developer Sandbox that [can be requested through Tableau.com](https://www.tableau.com/developer/get-site). ## Scope In this workflow, we: - Authenticate with Admin PAT to sign in - Search for the Workbook **"Superstore"**, and store the `workbook-id`, `workbook-name`, and `project-id` variables - Download the Workbook by clicking on the **down arrow** _near the Run button_ and clicking **Send and Download** - Publish the downloaded Workbook by following the steps below: - Select the Body by clicking on **Body** - Add the workbook downloaded in the previous step to the method body by clicking on **Select Files** - Click on the **Code** button in the right menu bar - Select **cUrl** in the dropdown - Copy the generated code and, outside of Postman, paste it into your Terminal, and execute it. - Back in Postman, Search for the Workbook **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook"**, and store the `workbook-id`, `workbook-name`, and `project-id` variables - Delete the workbook named **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook"** - Search for **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook"** without getting a positive result since the workbook was deleted - Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: This workflow uses Admin PAT authentication since JWT is not yet supported for the `Delete Workbook` method (as of API version 3.22)

twb or twbx to indicate whether you have uploaded a workbook file (twb) or a packaged workbook file (twbx). This value is required if you are calling Publish Workbook in order to commit a file that was previously uploaded using Append to File Upload. The value is not used if you upload a file in the body of the request.

If you are calling this method to commit a file that was uploaded in parts, this value contains the upload session ID that was generated by a call to Initiate File Upload. If this value is not included, the server assumes that the body of the request contains the file to be published.

(Optional, boolean) If false, the workbook publishing process runs as a synchronous process. If a workbook is very large, the process might time out before it finishes. If you set this value to true, the process runs asynchronously, and a job will start to perform the publishing process and return the job ID. You can check the status of the import job by calling Query Job. Default value is false.

item.description: ## ⚠️ Manual Flow ⚠️ Due to a Postman [incompatibility](https://github.com/postmanlabs/postman-app-support/issues/11471) (as of 05/11/24), this workflow can't use the Postman "Run" feature but requires to manually trigger the API calls by: - Selecting the method in the left folder panel - Clicking the **Send** button in the top right corner - Repeat the above for the next method ## Scope In this workflow, we: - Authenticate with Admin PAT to sign in - Create a **"DEV Postman Workflow"** project pre-loaded with sample workbooks, and store the `project-id` and `project-name` variables - Search for the Workbook named **"Superstore"** located in the project **"DEV Postman Workflow"**, and store the `workbook-id` , `workbook-name`, and `project-id` variables - Add a tag **"ReadyForDev"** to the workbook **"Superstore"** - Get a list of all workbooks with the tag "ReadyForDev", and store the `workbook-id` variables - Download the Workbook by clicking on the **down arrow** _near the Run button_ and clicking **Send and Download** - Create an empty **"PROD Postman Workflow"** project, and store the `project-id` and `project-name` variables - Publish the downloaded Workbook by following the steps below: - Select the Body by clicking on **Body** - Add the workbook downloaded in the previous step to the method body by clicking on Select Files - Click on the **Code** button in the right menu bar - Select **cUrl** in the dropdown - Copy the generated code and, outside of Postman, paste it into your Terminal, and execute it. - Back in Postman, delete the tag **"ReadyForProd"** from the _Dev_ workbook **"Superstore"** - Get a list of all workbooks with the tag "ReadyForDev" which returns no results since we deleted the tag - Search for the project **"PROD Postman Workflow"** and store the variable `project-id` - Delete the project named **"PROD Postman Workflow"** - Search for the project **"DEV Postman Workflow"** and store the variable `project-id` - Delete the project named **"DEV Postman Workflow"** - Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: This workflow uses Admin PAT authentication since JWT is not yet supported for a few methods (as of API version 3.22)
This folder is a collection of workflows that relates to Devops.

header.description:
The Tableau authentication header. The value is a credentials token from a Tableau server's response to an authentication request.
The Content-Type and Accept headers should be the mediatype of the request and response except in cases where you want to  [explicitly allow other versions of the resource](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm#per_resource_versioning).

query.description: Specifies the number of results in a paged response. Example: > `GET .../subscriptions?pageSize=50` **Combining Path Parameters:** A page_size expression can be combined with other path parameters using an ampersand (&) as a separator, and is typically used along with a page number expression. Learn more about paginating the response.

Specifies the page of items to be returned from a requested list. The value of `page_token` for the next page of returns is found in the `next_page_token` of the current response. If there are no further items to return, the value of `next_page_token` will be empty. Example: > `GET .../definitions?pageToken={next_page_value}` **Combining Path Parameters:** A page_token expression can be combined with other path parameters using an ampersand (&) as a separator, and is typically used along with a page number expression. Learn more about paginating the response.
The LUID of a user whose subscriptions will be returned.
The LUID of a metric whose subscriptions will be returned.

request.description:
Lists the subscriptions to a specified metric and/or for a specified user. If only `metric-id` is specified, all subscriptions for that metric are returned. If only `user-id` is specified, al subscriptions for that user are returned. If both `metric_id` or `user_id` and specified, then the user's subscription for the specified metric is returned. If no `metric_id` or `user_id` is specified, all subscriptions on the site will be returned. > **Version:** Available in API 3.21 (Tableau Cloud December 2023) and later. Not available for Tableau Server. *[Versioning Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm)* > **Permissions:** Any user that has **read** or **connect** permission to the data source used in the definition can list subscriptions. *[Permissions Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_permissions.htm)* > **License:** No additional license required. > **Access Scope:** tableau:metric_subscriptions:read
*Access Scopes Overview: [Cloud](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps_scopes.htm)*

query.description:
The range of metrics to return for a definition. The default is `DEFINITION_VIEW_BASIC` if not specified.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_BASIC` - Return only the specified metric definition.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_FULL` - Return the metric definition and the specified number of metrics.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_DEFAULT` - Return the metric definition and the default metric."
_(Required if `view` is `DEFINITION_VIEW_FULL`)_ The number of metrics to return.

request.description:
Gets a metric definition and optionally metrics it contains. > **Version:** Available in API 3.21 (Tableau Cloud December 2023) and later. Not available for Tableau Server. *[Versioning Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm)* > **Permissions:** Can be called by any user, but only returns definitions and metrics that the user has permissions to view. *[Permissions Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_permissions.htm)* > **License:** No additional license required. > **Access Scope:** tableau:insight_definitions_metrics:read
*Access Scopes Overview: [Cloud](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps_scopes.htm)*

item.description: ## Prerequisites This workflow requires the user to be subscribed to, at least, one Pulse metric. ## What is the Pulse Metric Value Bundle? The Pulse Metric Value Bundle contains the data used in the Pulse UI element below (and more): ## Scope In this workflow, we: 1. Authenticate with JWT to sign in and store the `user-id` variable 2. List all the Pulse metrics that the user is subscribed to and store the `metric_id` variable of the first metric listed 3. Get metric information and store the `definition_id` and `metric_specification` variables 4. Get metric definition information and store the `metric_name`, `metric_definition`, `extension_options`, `representation_options`, and `insights_options` variables 5. Generate the value insights bundle for the current metric 6. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: The **viz** objects (in the Value Bundle response) can be visualized by copy-pasting the json content into the [Online Vega Editor](https://vega.github.io/editor)

item.name: Generate a Pulse Metric Springboard Bundle

query.description: Specifies the number of results in a paged response. Example: > `GET .../subscriptions?pageSize=50` **Combining Path Parameters:** A page_size expression can be combined with other path parameters using an ampersand (&) as a separator, and is typically used along with a page number expression. Learn more about paginating the response.

Specifies the page of items to be returned from a requested list. The value of `page_token` for the next page of returns is found in the `next_page_token` of the current response. If there are no further items to return, the value of `next_page_token` will be empty. Example: > `GET .../definitions?pageToken={next_page_value}` **Combining Path Parameters:** A page_token expression can be combined with other path parameters using an ampersand (&) as a separator, and is typically used along with a page number expression. Learn more about paginating the response.
The LUID of a user whose subscriptions will be returned.
The LUID of a metric whose subscriptions will be returned.

request.description:
Lists the subscriptions to a specified metric and/or for a specified user. If only `metric-id` is specified, all subscriptions for that metric are returned. If only `user-id` is specified, al subscriptions for that user are returned. If both `metric_id` or `user_id` and specified, then the user's subscription for the specified metric is returned. If no `metric_id` or `user_id` is specified, all subscriptions on the site will be returned. > **Version:** Available in API 3.21 (Tableau Cloud December 2023) and later. Not available for Tableau Server. *[Versioning Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm)* > **Permissions:** Any user that has **read** or **connect** permission to the data source used in the definition can list subscriptions. *[Permissions Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_permissions.htm)* > **License:** No additional license required. > **Access Scope:** tableau:metric_subscriptions:read
*Access Scopes Overview: [Cloud](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps_scopes.htm)*

Not available for Tableau Server. *[Versioning Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm)* > **Permissions:** Any user get a metric's details as long as the user has **read** or **connect** access to the data source used in the definition. *[Permissions Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_permissions.htm)* > **License:** No additional license required. > **Access Scope:** tableau:insight_metrics:read
*Access Scopes Overview: [Cloud](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps_scopes.htm)*

query.description:
The range of metrics to return for a definition. The default is `DEFINITION_VIEW_BASIC` if not specified.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_BASIC` - Return only the specified metric definition.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_FULL` - Return the metric definition and the specified number of metrics.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_DEFAULT` - Return the metric definition and the default metric."
_(Required if `view` is `DEFINITION_VIEW_FULL`)_ The number of metrics to return.

item.description: ## Prerequisites This workflow requires the user to be subscribed to, at least, one Pulse metric. ## What is the Pulse Metric Springboard Bundle? The Pulse Metric Springboard Bundle contains the data used in the Pulse UI element below (and more): ## Scope In this workflow, we: 1. Authenticate with JWT to sign in and store the `user-id` variable 2. List all the Pulse metrics that the user is subscribed to and store the `metric_id` variable of the first metric listed 3. Get metric information and store the `definition_id` and `metric_specification` variables 4. Get metric definition information and store the `metric_name`, `metric_definition`, `extension_options`, `representation_options`, and `insights_options` variables 5. Generate the springboard insights bundle for the current metric 6. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: The **viz** objects (in the Value Bundle response) can be visualized by copy-pasting the json content into the [Online Vega Editor](https://vega.github.io/editor)

item.name: Generate a Pulse Metric Detail Bundle

query.description: Specifies the number of results in a paged response. Example: > `GET .../subscriptions?pageSize=50` **Combining Path Parameters:** A page_size expression can be combined with other path parameters using an ampersand (&) as a separator, and is typically used along with a page number expression. Learn more about paginating the response.

Specifies the page of items to be returned from a requested list. The value of `page_token` for the next page of returns is found in the `next_page_token` of the current response. If there are no further items to return, the value of `next_page_token` will be empty. Example: > `GET .../definitions?pageToken={next_page_value}` **Combining Path Parameters:** A page_token expression can be combined with other path parameters using an ampersand (&) as a separator, and is typically used along with a page number expression. Learn more about paginating the response.
The LUID of a user whose subscriptions will be returned.
The LUID of a metric whose subscriptions will be returned.

request.description:
Lists the subscriptions to a specified metric and/or for a specified user. If only `metric-id` is specified, all subscriptions for that metric are returned. If only `user-id` is specified, al subscriptions for that user are returned. If both `metric_id` or `user_id` and specified, then the user's subscription for the specified metric is returned. If no `metric_id` or `user_id` is specified, all subscriptions on the site will be returned. > **Version:** Available in API 3.21 (Tableau Cloud December 2023) and later. Not available for Tableau Server. *[Versioning Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_versions.htm)* > **Permissions:** Any user that has **read** or **connect** permission to the data source used in the definition can list subscriptions. *[Permissions Overview](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_concepts_permissions.htm)* > **License:** No additional license required. > **Access Scope:** tableau:metric_subscriptions:read
*Access Scopes Overview: [Cloud](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps_scopes.htm)*

query.description:
The range of metrics to return for a definition. The default is `DEFINITION_VIEW_BASIC` if not specified.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_BASIC` - Return only the specified metric definition.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_FULL` - Return the metric definition and the specified number of metrics.
- `DEFINITION_VIEW_DEFAULT` - Return the metric definition and the default metric."
_(Required if `view` is `DEFINITION_VIEW_FULL`)_ The number of metrics to return.

item.description: ## Prerequisites This workflow requires the user to be subscribed to, at least, one Pulse metric. ## What is the Pulse Metric Detail Bundle? The Pulse Metric Detail Bundle contains the data used in the Pulse UI element below (and more): ## Scope In this workflow, we: 1. Authenticate with JWT to sign in and store the `user-id` variable 2. List all the Pulse metrics that the user is subscribed to and store the `metric_id` variable of the first metric listed 3. Get metric information and store the `definition_id` and `metric_specification` variables 4. Get metric definition information and store the `metric_name`, `metric_definition`, `extension_options`, `representation_options`, and `insights_options` variables 5. Generate the detail insights bundle for the current metric 6. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: The **viz** objects (in the Value Bundle response) can be visualized by copy-pasting the json content into the [Online Vega Editor](https://vega.github.io/editor)
This folder is a collection of workflows that relates to Tableau Pulse.

item.name: Embedding Visualizations
Generate Excel Export

item.description: ## ⚠️ Manual Flow ⚠️ As of 04/08/24, there isn't a built-in feature in the Collection Runner or Newman that allows you to specify that certain requests should trigger a "Send and Download" action automatically. This workflow can't use the Postman "Run" feature but requires to manually trigger the API calls by: - Selecting the method in the left folder panel - Clicking the **Send** button in the top right corner - Repeat the above for the next method ## Prerequisites - This workflow requires an existing workbook named **"Superstore"** ideally located in a project named **"Sample"**. A **"Superstore"** workbook is available on newly deployed Tableau instances such as the free Tableau Cloud Developer Sandbox that [can be requested through Tableau.com](https://www.tableau.com/developer/get-site). ## Scope In this workflow, we: - Authenticate with JWT to sign in - Get a list of all worbooks, search for the one named **"Superstore"**, and store the `workbook-id` and `project-id` variables - Download the Workbook by clicking on the **down arrow** _near the Run button_ and clicking **Send and Download** - Publish the downloaded Workbook by following the steps below: - Select the Body by clicking on **Body** ``` - Add the workbook downloaded in the previous step to the method body by clicking on Select Files ``` - Click on the **Code** button in the right menu bar - Select **cUrl** in the dropdown - Copy the generated code and, outside of Postman, paste it into your Terminal. - Back in Postman, get a list of all worbooks, search for the one named **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook"**, and store the `workbook-id` variable - Delete the workbook named **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook"** - Get a list of all worbooks, search for the one named **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook". The workbook is not** - Search for **"Postman Workflow Published Workbook"** and get an error, as expected, since the workbook was deleted - Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: This workflow uses Admin PAT authentication since JWT is not yet supported for the `Delete Workbook` method (as of API version 3.22)

item.description: ## ⚠️ Manual Flow ⚠️ Due to a Postman flow not being able to persist image responses when using the Postman "Run" feature (as of 04/08/24), this workflow requires to manually trigger the API calls by: - Selecting the method in the left folder panel - Clicking the **Send** button in the top right corner - Repeat the above for the next method ## Prerequisites - This workflow requires an existing workbook named **"Superstore"** that contains a view named **"Overview"** ideally located in a project named **"Sample"**. A **"Superstore"** workbook is available on newly deployed Tableau instances such as the free Tableau Cloud Developer Sandbox that [can be requested through Tableau.com](https://www.tableau.com/developer/get-site). ## Scope In this workflow, we: 1. Authenticate with JWT to sign in 2. Search for the Workbook named **"Superstore"**, and store the `workbook-id` , `workbook-name`, and `project-id` variables 3. Search for the view **"Overview"** from the Workbook **"Superstore"**, and store the `view-id` and `view-name` variables 4. Get a low resolution thumbnail image of the view 5. Get a high resolution image of the view 6. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token > Note: While this workflow uses JWT via Connected Apps for authentication, alternative authentication mechanisms are also available

item.description:
## Prerequisites

- This workflow requires an existing workbook named **"Superstore"** that contains a view named **"Overview"** ideally located in a project named **"Sample"**. A **"Superstore"** workbook is available on newly deployed Tableau instances such as the free Tableau Cloud Developer Sandbox that [can be requested through Tableau.com](https://www.tableau.com/developer/get-site).
    

## Scope

In this workflow, we:

- Authenticate with JWT to sign in
    
- Search for the Workbook named **"Superstore"**, and store the `workbook-id` , `workbook-name`, and `project-id` variables
    
- Search for the view **"Overview"** from the Workbook **"Superstore"**, and store the `view-id` and `view-name` variables
    
- Get a CSV representation of the view data
    
- Get a CSV representation of the view data filtered on the value "United States"
- Sign out, invalidating the authentication token
    

> Note: The csv data is often parsed to then be rendered by the parent application. Fiiltering can be passed directly through the query: [view documentation](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_ref_workbooks_and_views.htm#query_view_data)

item.description:
In this workflow, we:

1. Authenticate with JWT to sign in
2. Create a user group named **"Demo Group Name"** and store the `group-id` variable
3. Search for **"Demo Group Name"** and store `group-id` and `group-name` variables
4. Update our user group name to **"Updated Demo Group Name"**
5. Search for **"Updated Demo Group Name"** and store `group-id` and `group-name` variables
6. List all the users in **"Updated Demo Group Name"** and find none
7. Create a new user **"DemoGroupUser1@test.com"** and store the `user-id` variable
8. Add user **"DemoGroupUser1@test.com"** to **"Updated Demo Group Name"**
9. List all the users in **"Updated Demo Group Name"** and find **"DemoGroupUser1@test.com"**
10. Delete user **"DemoGroupUser1@test.com"**
11. List all the users in **"Updated Demo Group Name"** and find none
12. Search for **"DemoGroupUser1@test.com"** and get an error, as expected, since the user was deleted
13. Delete group **"Updated Demo Group Name"**
14. Search for **"Updated Demo Group Name"** and retreive no result since the group was removed
    
15. Sign out, invalidating the authentication token
    

> Note: While this workflow uses JWT via Connected Apps for authentication, alternative authentication mechanisms are also available

item.description:
See [VizQL Data Service Documentation](https://help.tableau.com/current/api/vizql-data-service/en-us/index.html)

In this workflow, we will query fields from "Superstore Datasource" on our site. It has the following steps:

1. Use the Tableau REST API [Sign in (JWT)](https://www.postman.com/salesforce-developers/salesforce-developers/request/o7edvtd/sign-in-jwt) to authenticate your session.
    
    1. Use the scope `tableau:viz_data_service:read` when you [create the JWT.](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps_direct.htm#step-3-configure-the-jwt)
        
2. Execute the Tableau REST API [Query Data Sources](https://www.postman.com/hbi-postman-to-tableau/workspace/tableaurestapifork/request/40420331-d983845f-798a-4582-b26f-8d239c9cb9fd) on the site
    
    1. This request has a post request script that will find the datasource called SuperstoreDatasource, and set the environment variable `datasource-id` with the correct datasource luid
        
3. Run Read Metadata for a given datasource, which displays all of the query-able fields for the datasource given
    
4. Run Query Datasource for a couple fields in Superstore Datasource, displaying the Sum of Sales broken down by Category
    
5. Use the Tableau REST API [Sign out ](https://www.postman.com/salesforce-developers/salesforce-developers/request/6450lzj/sign-out) method to end the session.

Welcome to the Tableau REST API Sample Workflows folder. This folder is designed to offer you a hands-on experience with sample workflows that leverage the Tableau REST APIs to perform complex business operations and demonstrate the transformative potential of automation in data analytics. ### Automated Workflows The workflows in this folder go beyond simple API aggregation. They include test scripts that automate the storage of variables passed between API methods, allowing you to execute an entire flow of API calls in just a few clicks. ### Contextual Learning The primary goal of this collection is to educate and inspire. Whether you're new to Tableau or an experienced user, these workflows are designed to broaden your understanding of what's possible with Tableau's REST APIs and automation. Each workflow is equipped with Postman tests that not only validate the responses but also provide contextual explanations, making it easier for you to understand the logic and purpose behind each step. ### Before Executing A Workflow / Prerequisites - Have a Tableau instance to connect to with Admin privileges. A free Tableau Cloud Developer Sandbox [can be requested through Tableau.com](https://www.tableau.com/developer/get-site). - Set up your own fork of the collection and prepare your Postman environement using the following instructions: [How to Use the Collection](https://github.com/tableau/tableau-postman/blob/main/README.md#how-to-use-the-collection). - Configure Connected Apps authentication using the following instructions: [How to Configure Connected Apps](https://help.tableau.com/current/online/en-us/connected_apps.htm). - Configure your Postman Environment to use Connected Apps by storing the following environement variables: `jwt_secret`, `jwt_secret_id`, `jwt_client_id`, `admin-PAT-name`, and `admin-PAT-secret`. > Note: While most of the workflows use JWT via Connected Apps for authentication, some use Admin PAT when using REST API endpoints that don't yet support JWT. Alternative authentication methods are also available. ### How To Execute A Workflow To execute a workflow automation: - Select the desired workflow folder - Click the **Run** button in the top right corner - Check the **Persist responses for a session** box so you can review the responses of each API call - Click **Run Tableau REST API** - See the test results and comment after each query on the left part of the screen - Click on a query to see its query response in the right panel This user-friendly process ensures that you can focus on learning and innovation rather than setup and configuration. ### Customization and Contribution Users are encouraged to use these workflows as a starting point to create their own customized solutions. Your innovations are valuable, and we invite you to contribute to the collection. You can find contribution guidelines and procedures in the root folder. By exploring and utilizing these workflows, you'll gain practical knowledge that can be applied to your own business scenarios. Dive in to discover how automation can elevate your data analytics and reporting processes with Tableau REST APIs.
